text.p: These are the stories making headlines in the Namibian press on Monday. Retuers has not verifired these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Because of finanical constraints the Swapo central committee has decided to appoint only four of the 14 positions for national organisers, deferring the decision to appoint more to a later stage.

- The Namibian Broadcasting Corporation (NBC) is to seek an additional N$13 million from government to implement a new salary structure agreed upon between management and staff representatives on Friday.

- The national planning commission (NPC) will as from today (Monday) be conducting a month-long country-wide research to establish a national consumer index, permanent secretary of the NPC Andrew Ndishishi announced on Friday.
- President Sam Nujoma called on the Swapo membership to take stock of the successes and failures of the ruling party during the central committee meeting on Saturday.

- There was a radical change in the formation of the politbureau of the ruling party Swapo with the absence of the former party leader Moses Garoeb the clearest indication that a further cabinet reshuffle is on the cards.
- A new democratic party is being hailed as the answer to Swapo's political monopoly in four regions in northern Namibia.

- Expressing his concern about the recent collapse of ostrich prices, Stephanus Goliath, chairman of Ostrich Production Namibia, and Karas regional governor, said that rumours about the impending financial difficulties of the industry would not only hurt existing projects, but OPN as well.
- The transport parastatal Transnamib signed an annual wage agreemeent with the Namibia Transport and Allied Union (NATAU) last week.
